awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Consumer Behavior-Aware Learning for Revenue Management
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) award supports research on novel, consumer behavior aware design of online marketplaces through advances in online machine learning techniques. This grant will benefit U. S. consumers and service providers and contribute to an increased competitiveness of the e-commerce sector by addressing critical challenges faced in revenue management and operations of modern marketplaces. With the ubiquity of online customer review platforms, price aggregators, discussion forums, and connected communities, the modern consumer displays increasing tendencies to form socially influenced opinions, imitate other users, learn and anticipate prices, and time their purchases. Market mechanisms that fail to account for such consumer behavior can result in significant losses in terms of revenue, inventory, and consumer welfare. This project will leverage the opportunity presented by the abundance of consumer activity data to learn and account for consumer behavior when designing market pricing and allocation mechanisms. The research conducted will benefit both consumers and sellers through a more efficient matching of demand and supply. The educational and outreach initiatives of this program will enable inclusive participation and engagement of students at all levels, and promote interdisciplinary, hands-on education in data science and decision making. 

The research plan of this project addresses some critical gaps in the current online machine learning techniques, which are typically designed assuming independent and identically distributed or exogenously generated data; and therefore, are ill suited to handle the endogeneity that may result from frequent social interactions and strategic consumer. The research plan investigates new learning techniques for dynamic pricing, recommendation, and allocation under three broad classes of commonly occurring consumer behavior: (1) social influence and imitation, (2) forward-looking and planning behavior, and (3) consumer learning behavior. For each of these categories, it will develop new models and decision-making frameworks that can capture natural and uncertain consumer behavior while being conducive to learning.  New methods for exploration-exploitation, dynamic learning, and online optimization will be developed, which will build upon and advance tools from multi-armed bandits, online convex optimization, dynamic programming, and reinforcement learning. These new solution techniques will be accompanied with rigorous theoretical analysis as well as performance evaluation in real markets through collaboration with industry partners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the ubiquity of online customer review platforms, price aggregators, discussion forums, and connected communities, the modern consumers display increasing tendencies to imitate other users, form socially influenced opinions, learn and anticipate prices, and time their purchases. Failure to account for these behavioral dynamics can result in unexpected responses to market mechanisms and pricing strategies. At the same time, with proper handling, phenomena like social imitation and learning can be utilized to achieve a better matching of demand and supply. The abundance of purchase and behavioral data in the form of click-stream logs, customer reviews, ratings, and social feeds, presents a unique opportunity for learning these consumer behavioral patterns and the demand dynamics, and for leveraging this understanding to design a more efficient marketplace. These observations drove this project’s investigation into data-driven, learning-based approaches for dynamic pricing that can account for and utilize such behaviors. 

A main outcome of the project was new modeling frameworks that can capture natural consumer behavior while being conducive to learning. Specifically, the project investigated three kinds of consumer behavior: a) social influence and imitation, b) forward-looking strategic behavior, and c) consumer learning behavior. It contributed new robust learning and decision-making mechanisms in the face of consumer behavior. 

Specifically (in work published in EC 2024, NeurIPS 2023, EC 2021), we presented novel frameworks that capture customers’ behavioral response to past market prices and product adoptions. Intuitively, past popularity of a product among other customers can influence a customer’s response to the current price, a phenomenon referred to as social imitation. This requires new mechanisms for learning and dynamic pricing. Similarly, a price lower (higher) than the average of past prices (aka reference price) can be perceived as a bargain (loss) by a consumer, and can invoke a variety of positive or negative responses. The work contributed new algorithms that provably optimize long-term outcomes under such consumer behaviors. In another work (Neurips 2022), we presented new mechanisms for online allocation and learning in the presence of strategic agents who may have incentives to misreport their valuations in order to receive better allocations from an online learning-based mechanism. 

Another important area that this project made contributions to was in handling heterogeneous behaviors. In practice, different buyers on a platform may display different response behaviors depending on their risk attitudes and trust in the platform. Furthermore, such buyer attitudes may not be visible to the platform. A main thrust of this project was to present mechanisms (work published in EC 2021) that are robust to such heterogeneous buyer behavior. Strong upper and lower bounds on platform’s revenue were derived under an arbitrary pool of heterogeneous customers.

Finally, the project made several methodological contributions (e.g., two works published in Operations Research Journal 2022) to the algorithm design and theory of online learning and reinforcement learning. It presented novel reinforcement learning algorithms along with mathematical analysis techniques that advance foundational techniques in these areas, and are applicable across application domains that involve learning under large Markov Decision Processes.
